Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The University of Southern Maine is the only regional comprehensive university in the state, and situated in the most diverse region of the state. As a result of its commitment to creating a culture and environment for attaining and sustaining a diverse faculty population that reflects the community it serves, the Southern Maine ADVANCE IT Catalyst project will focus on a comprehensive quantitative and qualitative assessment of systemic institutional factors affecting recruitment, retention, and advancement of women in the STEM disciplines. Major activities include, but are not limited to: collecting and analyzing baseline data, collecting and reviewing information about best practices and lessons learned and developing a data-driven, evidence-based institutional transformational readiness plan to support women faculty. Results from this project are expected to yield sustained transformation that will positively impact the number of women faculty who could serve as role models to a growing population of non-traditional and female students, especially women veterans, and provide the institution with the necessary platform to serve as a model for other comprehensive universities that share some of the same unique characteristics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Southern Maine is accredited by the New England Association of Schools and College and is Maine's only public, regional, comprehensive university with campuses in Portland, Gorham, and Lewiston-Auburn Maine. The University of Southern Maine's ADVANCE IT-Catalyst Planning Grant (WAUI) offered the institution the opportunity to develop a systematic approach to addressing factors that have resulted in the underrepresentation of women faculty in STEM and Social Sciences disciplines. The objectives of the grant were to assess the current status of women STEM and Social Sciences faculty to obtain qualitative and quantitative information to understand the extent of the barriers to recruitment, employment, retention and promotion of women in STEM and Social Sciences faculty positions, establish institutional peer relationships with comprehensive universities in order to share experiences and lessons learned and through the presentation and publication of data and the development of programs, workshops, and symposia, lay the groundwork for institutional transformation. The WAUI was housed within the Office of the Provost, placing it at the center of the institution. An Advisory Board representing senior faculty leadership, the Offices of Equity and Compliance, Human Resources, Equity and Compliance and STEM and Social Sciences department chairs was established and met throughout the project to disseminate information on assessment initiatives, assist in the collection of department and college data, resolve project issues and assist in the development of an institutional transformation plan. 

Baseline data was collected to assess institutional trends and provide more clarity in understanding the dynamics of the institution. The assessment plan also included a review of current policies and practices and the academic climate. The Assessment of the academic climate at USM, including particular issues involving gender, race/ethnicity, sexual orientation and national origin were assessed by way of an on-line climate survey, focus groups and town meetings. Three university-wide working committees were established to examine policies and practices in three critical areas: a) recruitment and hiring, b) retention, promotion and tenure, and c) work-family life. Committee members were appointed by the Provost and represented faculty administrators as well as senior and junior faculty. A web site was developed to promote and publicize WAUI initiatives on campus and the USM Blackboard system enabled groups and - discussions.

An important component our of grant was to learn from other comprehensive universities and establish "Institutional Peer and Mentor" relationships with existing ADVANCE IT institutions. The University of Maine (UMaine) was identified as an institutional mentor. We also targeted Southern Illinois University at Edwardsville and the State University of New York at Oswego as institutional peers.Three site visits to peer and mentor institutions enabled the USM grantees to gain valuable insights into their respective experiences and lessons learned. In order to make institutional transformation possible and raise awareness on campus the results of the analyses were presented to different campus groups and highlighted in town meetings. As part of the effort to raise awareness, a symposium was held during the project period to iun crease awareness of how women faculty are enhancing campus environment, education and research in STEM and Social Sciences. Once a semester for two semesters we invited keynote speakers,  women who had been hired by and benefited from institutions with long running, successful, and nationally recognized ADVANCE programs to highlight the important work ahead and help provide insights into planning for the long term goal of WAUI to increase the representation and success of women faculty in STEM and Social Sciences disciplines at the University of Southern Maine.
